posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked:
Why payments in messaging app

It is simply intuitive to be able to pay directly to my contacts without additional communication about how do we want to transfer money.

Why Bitcoin

There is a lot of reasoning, but to make it simple. Bitcoin works worldwide and without permission. And in this manner it has the biggest adoption.

Lightning network fits to privacy focus of Signal

Why specifically at Signal app

It’s simply the best private chat and already having a good network effect (using phone numbers)

I’ve only read a few discussions. But I haven’t found anything very constructive. How do you feel about this? Do you plan to do it in the future or do you think it’s nonsense?

What is needed to make it happen? How can I help?

  • Rise some funds?
  • Technical feasibility?
  • UX study?
  • Something else?

Thanks for your effort.

In case you missed it, Signal already does have a payments feature:

Signal Support

In-app Payments

Requirements Why do I need to change my Signal PIN? Supported cryptocurrencies Activate Payments Payments details View Transactions Network Fee & Coin Cleanup Fee Currency Conversion Send P...

The question is whether they would want to expand that to Bitcoin. I believe they did state somewhere that they were open to considering other cryptocurrency.

posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked: Yes, I know about this… But I don’t think that it would be beneficial to have a whole jungle of available coins. But rather select the one with the biggest impact. Which is Bitcoin.

hynek:

Why Bitcoin

Why not Bitcoin: environmental impact.

Signal Messenger

Help us test payments in Signal

The latest Signal betas are rolling out today. Inside, you’ll find performance enhancements, a slew of bug fixes, improvements to the mute settings, and if you’re in the United Kingdom, you’ll see support for Signal Payments – a new feature that...

Signal Messenger

Update on beta testing payments in Signal

As the world stands today, the future of transaction privacy does not look great. The existing landscape is dominated by traditional credit companies, who over the past decade have been steadily pushing their networks for increased access to user...

These are two blog posts you might want to read, but here are the most relevant parts:

We want payments in Signal to be fast, private, and work well on mobile devices.

[A]ny cryptocurrency wallets that we include support for also have to work well from within Signal. This would mean:

  1. Integration is “non-custodial”: Signal does not have access to your keys or your funds; that information remains associated with your own wallet.
  2. Like everything else in Signal, data is private: all your data stays in your hands rather than being visible to others.
  3. Transactions are fast: like Venmo, it can only take a few seconds to send a transaction.
  4. Everything works well on mobile: it can’t require downloading and scanning all ongoing transactions in order to find your own.
  5. The experience is simple: in most other ways the experience should be the same as something like Venmo.
  6. It can scale to hundreds of millions of people.

And finally, a quote from Moxie:

Signal did not create MC. Have said many times would support integrating BTC or LN if it is made to be private, fast, no/low fee, works on mobile (doesn’t require scanning every tx to identify your own), etc.

posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked:
Thank you.
So it is about technical feasibility, right?
And from your 6 point I believe that only the number 1 is to be tackled. Others already work.
Do you agree?

posts.name: AlertSubject
posts.cooked:
What about Dash as a currency?
Seems more like it was developed for such things

I don’t think I’m going to continue this discussion further, as I’m not well versed in particular cryptocurrencies design, and I was against integrating any of them into Signal.

Those points are taken straight from Signal’s Blog - I edited the original post, so that it’s clear.

Regarding Bitcoin and Signal:

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Bitcoin is extremely counter to Signal’s goal of being a privacy-focused messaging app - all Bitcoin transactions are open to all of the world to see. It is not anonymous, but pseudonymous - the moment someone knows your address, they know your history. Your boss can see any place you ever purchased from. That guy you paid back after he paid for your date can see how many other guys you dated. etc etc.
And that’s even before we talk about the enormous environmental impact of Bitcoin.
I don’t like Signal having MobileCoin in the first place. It puts a strain on the vision of privacy, and cryptoassets in general tend to be used as a purely speculative vessel, which is just short of being an outright scam. But at least MobileCoin is not as bad as Bitcoin.

link_counts.title: How Signal is playing with fire - The Verge

posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked: But you are talking about first layer of bitcoin. Lightning has a great privacy and there is basically no environmental impact related to lightning payments.

posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked: Than you for your answer…

@TeeJay82

Why not Bitcoin: environmental impact.

You might want to read this: Bitcoin Mining and the Environment

@rassilon1963

Bitcoin is extremely counter to Signal’s goal of being a privacy-focused messaging app

I can agree with that to some degree since the main goal of Bitcoin was not to solve financial privacy.

all Bitcoin transactions are open to all of the world to see.

No, they no longer are. Second layer transactions are only visible to the sender and recipient using onion routing.

And that’s even before we talk about the enormous environmental impact of Bitcoin.

You might also want to read the link provided to @TeeJay82

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
ekzyis:

No, they no longer are. Second layer transactions are only visible to the sender and recipient using onion routing.

Second layer networks currently account for 0.025% of the network’s volume. Also, I think the comparison to onion routing is not very appropriate, since by participating or even by the very nature of closing a channel, correlation attacks are much easier to do. That’s in addition to other vulnerabilities found in the network.
But even if the transactions were fully hidden by second layer networks and 100% of transactions were made via them, it is still very easy to correlate an address to a person and know their precise balance. And if that does not make you uncomfortable, please post a screenshot of your balance from your bank online app below.

link_counts.title: Researchers Highlight Privacy Issues With Lightning Network

posts.cooked:
hynek:

Lightning has a great privacy

Is the suggestion that Signal would manage channels for users? If so, that is not private at all.

If Signal doesn’t manage channels, then we’re just talking about having Lightning Address links and that is not a good UX (only the tech savvy could understand what’s going on).

posts.name: Hynek Jína
posts.cooked:
For example with Fedimint you can manage channels to users and still have no information about their transactions (with zero knowledge proofs)

Or similar solution to Phoenix Wallet - non-custodial.

Talya (she/her):

That’s in addition to other vulnerabilities found in the network.

Fixed random short channel id for private channels · Issue #675 · lightning/bolts · GitHub

There are many possibilities to inregrate Bitcoin into Signal. The trade-off between Privacy and Usability is imanent, and projects like Signal are proof of its increasing resolution.

However, the integration of an alternative crypro-currency, with the argument of a privacy ethos, simply ignores trade-offs on the network protocol level, which in return can have significant impact on privacy again. If that would be financial regulation or the trivial fact that behind MobileCoin stands another company, which means high counter party risk. PoW is here the central difference.

It would be refreshing to see an effort by Signal to at least connect in a way with bitcoin so that bitcoiners are satisfied. Also there is so much happening right now within the extended Bitcoin space (Chaumanian eCash, NOSTR) that could be interesting for Signal dev folks.

Otherwise, we bitcoiners will need (again) to move to another platform, that hopefully agrees to the underlying conclusions of our ethos.

posts.name: Hardisk
posts.cooked:
I’d like to bump this thread as I think this is important to Signal. As 2024 is well ahead, I think Bitcoin and Lightning integration should be a core feature of Signal.

Here are some key points to consider, please feel free to contribute to this discussion, the Payment integration has been in the app for a few years now and isn’t really getting used.

→ MobileCoin cannot be easily purchased from many countries, including the USA, the coin is also getting delisted from major exchanges (including Binance) on April 3rd.

→ MobileCoin’s supply is slanted, meaning the creators of Mobilecoin owns most of the supply, the integration of MobileCoin inside a popular app like Signal gave an unfair economic advantage to an insider group.

→ Bitcoin and Lightning can in fact be run privately, if Signal runs a lightning node that administers channels for it’s users it does not have to be aware of who they are, users can redeem Bitcoin Lightning funds to the main Bitcoin network at any time to an address of their choosing and can manage their level of privacy how they see fit with those addresses

→ Bitcoin is never going away or getting delisted, it’s actually very largely used for payments in many parts of the world and still growing : Record Year for Crypto Payments Growth: 2023 Report | CoinGate

→ Bitcoin is provably fair to everyone, through it’s PoW consensus mechanism the “rich always get richer” problem of PoS goes away. Nobody has created coins out of thing air to make it rich.

→ The infamous “enormous energy use” problem is getting more and more analysed as Bitcoin helps power grids accross the world get rid of the “lost energy problem” and fund green energy bids. See the following ressources, articles, and peer reviewed papers. Bitcoin may be a great ally to energy transition after alll :

  • [Video] World Economic Forum on LinkedIn: Virunga is the first national park to own a bitcoin mine. Learn more about… | 22 comments

  • Why Bitcoin Mining Might Actually Be Great For Sustainability

  • https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acssuschemeng.2c06077

link_counts.title: [Video] World Economic Forum on LinkedIn: Virunga is the first national park to own a bitcoin mine. Learn more about… | 22 comments
Why Bitcoin Mining Might Actually Be Great For Sustainability
Record Year for Crypto Payments Growth: 2023 Report | CoinGate

posts.cooked:
Great suggestion. Any other coin than Bitcoin will have the problem of unfair initial distribution, VCs, and high risk of going away in the future. Bitcoin has been top of the list for 15 years now, I think it’s safer to assume it’s not going away than the opposite.

Underlying the energy issue is also becoming a non-topic as you say, now that academics (Cornell, UCL, U of South Carolina…) have finally started to analyse it, and not only Central Bankers, we are getting more and more analysis showing Bitcoin is actually part of the solution, and not the problem.

The combo of a great private messaging app like Signal and an open source currency and payment system like Bitcoin seems obvious to me as a user.
